anchoring.content:

What was the surname of the woman who was the inspiration behind the Rolling Stones song Angie?

Passages:
['Angie Bowie has long claimed to have inspired The Rolling Stones\' hit song "Angie" from their 1973 album "Goats Head Soup". However, the songwriters Mick Jagger and Keith Richards have consistently denied this. In 1993, in the liner notes to the Rolling Stones\' compilation album "", Richards said that the title was inspired by his newborn daughter, Dandelion Angela. Later, in his 2010 memoir "Life", he said that he had chosen the name at random when writing the song and that "[i]t was not about any particular person." According to "NME", the lyrics of the song were inspired by Jagger\'s breakup with Marianne Faithfull.\n', 'BULLET::::- Angie Stone (born 1961), American R&B singer\n', 'BULLET::::- Angie Stone (b. Angela Laverne Brown), an American R&B, soul, and neo soul singer-songwriter, keyboardist, record producer, and occasional actress\n', '– Angie (The Rolling Stones cover) Instrumental\n', 'Angie Stone (born Angela Laverne Brown; December 18, 1965) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and record producer. She rose to fame in the late 1970s as member of the hip hop trio The Sequence. Soon after, Stone began working with futuristic rap group Mantronix and singer Lenny Kravitz. In the early 1990s, she became a member of the R&B trio Vertical Hold. In 1999, Stone released her solo debut "Black Diamond" on Arista Records, which was certified gold and spawned the R&B number-one hit "No More Rain (In This Cloud)". After transitioning to J Records, she released another gold-seller, "Mahogany Soul" (2001), which included the hit single "Wish I Didn\'t Miss You", followed by "Stone Love" (2004) and "The Art of Love & War" (2007), her first number-one album on the US "Billboard" Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart.\n', 'BULLET::::- Angie Stone, singer\n', 'BULLET::::- The Rolling Stones - Angie (1973)\n', 'BULLET::::- Angie Stone — Arranger, Producer, Vocal Arrangement\n', 'Angie Stone\n', 'Angie Stone\n']

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

The song "Angie" by the Rolling Stones has been the subject of various interpretations regarding its inspiration. While it is commonly believed that the song may have been inspired by a woman named Angela, the most frequently cited surname associated with this belief is "Bowie," referring to Angie Bowie, the wife of musician David Bowie. However, it is crucial to note that both Mick Jagger and Keith Richards, the songwriters, have denied that the song was specifically about Angie Bowie.

1. **Angie Bowie’s Claim**: Angie Bowie has publicly claimed to be the inspiration for the song "Angie." This assertion is significant as it reflects a personal connection that she believes exists between her and the song.

2. **Denial by Songwriters**: Jagger and Richards have consistently denied that the song was written about Angie Bowie. This contradiction highlights the complexity of attributing inspiration to a specific individual.

3. **Keith Richards' Explanation**: In 1993, Keith Richards mentioned that the title "Angie" was inspired by his newborn daughter, Dandelion Angela. He later clarified that he chose the name at random while writing the song. This suggests that the name "Angie" was not necessarily linked to any particular person, which contradicts the notion that it was specifically about Angie Bowie.

4. **Jagger's Breakup Influence**: Additionally, the lyrics of "Angie" were reportedly influenced by Jagger's breakup with Marianne Faithfull. This context provides further insight into the emotional backdrop of the song, indicating that it may not be centered around any one individual.

In summary, while Angie Bowie claims to be the inspiration for "Angie," this is disputed by the songwriters, who have indicated that the name was chosen randomly and that the song's themes were influenced by personal experiences unrelated to Bowie. Therefore, the surname of the woman often associated with the song is "Bowie," but the actual inspiration is more nuanced and involves multiple influences.

**Answer:** Bowie

question_info.question: What was the surname of the woman who was the inspiration behind the Rolling Stones song Angie?
passages:
Angie Bowie has long claimed to have inspired The Rolling Stones' hit song "Angie" from their 1973 album "Goats Head Soup". However, the songwriters Mick Jagger and Keith Richards have consistently denied this. In 1993, in the liner notes to the Rolling Stones' compilation album "", Richards said that the title was inspired by his newborn daughter, Dandelion Angela. Later, in his 2010 memoir "Life", he said that he had chosen the name at random when writing the song and that "[i]t was not about any particular person." According to "NME", the lyrics of the song were inspired by Jagger's breakup with Marianne Faithfull.
BULLET::::- Angie Stone (born 1961), American R&B singer
BULLET::::- Angie Stone (b. Angela Laverne Brown), an American R&B, soul, and neo soul singer-songwriter, keyboardist, record producer, and occasional actress
– Angie (The Rolling Stones cover) Instrumental
Angie Stone (born Angela Laverne Brown; December 18, 1965) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and record producer. She rose to fame in the late 1970s as member of the hip hop trio The Sequence. Soon after, Stone began working with futuristic rap group Mantronix and singer Lenny Kravitz. In the early 1990s, she became a member of the R&B trio Vertical Hold. In 1999, Stone released her solo debut "Black Diamond" on Arista Records, which was certified gold and spawned the R&B number-one hit "No More Rain (In This Cloud)". After transitioning to J Records, she released another gold-seller, "Mahogany Soul" (2001), which included the hit single "Wish I Didn't Miss You", followed by "Stone Love" (2004) and "The Art of Love & War" (2007), her first number-one album on the US "Billboard" Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart.
BULLET::::- Angie Stone, singer
BULLET::::- The Rolling Stones - Angie (1973)
BULLET::::- Angie Stone — Arranger, Producer, Vocal Arrangement
Angie Stone
